tit.e: Michikiri (a folk custom practiced on roads or crossroads at the entrance to villages)

sen.j: 道切り（みちきり）とは、村（地域）の出入り口にあたる道や辻で行われる民俗習慣のひとつ。
sen.e: Michikiri is one of the folk customs practiced on a road or crossroad as an entrance of the village (region).
Michikiri is a folk custom practiced on roads or crossroads at the entrance to villages (or regions).
Michikiri is a folk custom practiced on roads or crossroads at the entrance to villages (or regions).

sen.j: 辻切り（つじぎり）とも称される。
日本の村落においては、村と山の境界にあたる野良（ノラ）、あるいは村と村の境（サカイ）には古くから魔や疫病をはやらせる神などが出入りすると考えられていた。
sen.e: In Japanese villages, it was thought evil spirits, and a god spreading a plague go through nora, the border of the mountain and village, or sakai, that of the villages, from ancient times.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In Japanese villages, it has been believed since ancient times that evil spirits and plague-spreading gods come and go across the 'norai', the border between mountains and village, or the 'sakai', the border between villages.

sen.j: 出入り口にあたる道には魔を防いだり、追い払うために道祖神が祀られたり、注連縄（または藁で作った蛇）を張ったり草履や草鞋が供えるなどの道切り行事が行われていた。
sen.e: Events of Michikiri was done by enshrining Doso-shin (traveller's guardian deity), putting up Shimenawa (sacred rice-straw ropes) and offering Zori (Japanese sandals) or Waraji (straw sandals) in order to prevent or drive away evil spirits on a street as the entrance.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: During michikiri, where the road enters the village, Doso-shin (traveler's guardian deity) is enshrined, sacred shimenawa ropes (or sometimes snakes made of straw) are hung and 'zori' or 'waraji' sandals are offered to the gods in order to prevent or drive away evil spirits.

sen.j: なお、この行事の行われる時期については、地域によって異なるが定期的に行われるか、時により臨時に行われることがある。
sen.e: Though the period to hold this event varies regionally, it is held on a regular basis or possibly temporary basis.
